chunks.en:
I'm currently studying in France and found a three-person shared apartment for cheap, but one of my roommates is a total man-child.
This person is a second-year master's student, at least 25 years old physically, but his behavior and logic are completely childlike.
This morning I woke up and opened the door to a terrible smell. It turned out the pot was burnt. His explanation was that he set a timer for the stove, but it didn't seem to work, and then he left... Another roommate who woke up earlier turned off the fire. After saying that, his eyes went back to the screen, which was showing a game. No apology either...
The kitchen sink is constantly piled with his pots and pans, and he only washes them when he cooks, I've told him five or six times, but he doesn't listen. Every time he finishes cooking, he rushes back to his room to play games, and even when he is cooking, he's playing games and doesn't watch the stove. Several times, other roommates have helped him turn off the fire.
He plays games and voice chats late at night, and ignores me even after I've told him several times to stop.
He leaves his clothes in the washing machine for two or three days after they're washed.
His family sent him abroad to study after the Gaokao (National College Entrance Examination), and I guess he had never been in the kitchen before being sent abroad. He knows nothing about kitchen safety and hygiene.
Tonight, I called him out of his room to warn him not to mess up the kitchen again. He also looked at you with one eye and the game on the screen with the other, his mind is only on the game.
If you talk to him nicely, he will only agree to everything in order to quickly go back to playing games. I'm too lazy to use any harsh tricks to deal with him. If it really doesn't work, I'll just move out and rather spend more money. Talking to this kind of man-child is a waste of life.

Venting to you v2ex users, and also to witness the wonders of the world.
Moving out sooner is the right thing to do.
Maybe he is from a wealthy family, consider building a good relationship.
This doesn't seem to have much to do with being a man-child, it's just being addicted to games ğŸ¤¨
It's also a man-child in a way. I've also seen people addicted to games but they manage not to affect those around them.
It's better to rent a place by yourself.

chunks.en: Either you are even more of a man-child than him, or move out. Even his 'biological dad' can't change this kind of person, let alone you. To be honest, this kind of person isn't that strange. At most, he affects your rest, has poor hygiene, and likes to play games. He didn't poop on your bed ğŸ˜„
Right now, it just seems like a gaming addiction. Cut off his power a few times and you'll know if he's a man-child.

@abc500 I've had it out with the landlord. Either he leaves or me and the other roommate leave. The landlord should know which side pays more, and keeping this kind of person is a scourge. He might even burn down the landlord's house.

It's easy for the landlord to solve this kind of thing. Hire a cleaning company to clean up the garbage every week and split the costs evenly. Every kitchen incident, hire a cleaning company to clean up and charge extra for cleaning and maintenance. Use the washing machine with coins. Install soundproofing panels in the rooms.
Find a girl to seduce him into moving in together, like Yu the Great controlling the floods, instead of blocking, try diverting. Then everything will be peaceful.
@toneal #9 He himself rents together, which means he lacks girls himself, how can he find girls for others?
This kind of person may already be endangering your personal safety, you must stay away.
This kind of person has no concept of public space and doesn't know what it means to not affect others. You can tell his upbringing is bad. Stay away from him as soon as possible.

From my experience, the best way to deal with this situation is to move out and live by yourself. Some people are incorrigible, nothing you say will work, you find him annoying, and he finds you annoying. Everyone has their own way of living, why bother.

I encountered this kind of situation a lot when I was studying in the United States. I've also encountered similar situations, including but not limited to not wiping the stove after cooking, not taking out the trash when it was their turn, and insisting on piling dirty dishes in the sink even though there was a dishwasher and they didn't have to pay for water. I usually say they learned Gandhi's non-violent non-cooperation very well.
Just thinking about it makes me feel suffocated.
Maybe he's used to being at home, having a mom, or being served by workers.
If you can't change him, move out.
